description: From Middle English comprisen, from Old French compris, past participle of comprendre, from Latin comprehendere, contr. comprendere, past participle comprehensus (“to comprehend”); see comprehend. Compare apprise, reprise, surprise.

verbs.description: comprise (third-person singular simple present comprises, present participle comprising, simple past and past participle comprised)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To be made up of; to consist of (especially a comprehensive list of parts). [from the earlier 15th c.]
examples: The parts are comprised by the whole.

entries.meaning: (sometimes proscribed, usually in the passive) To compose; to constitute. [from the late 18th c.]
examples: The whole is comprised of the parts.

entries.meaning: To contain or embrace. [from the earlier 15th c.]
examples: Our committee comprises a president, secretary, treasurer and five other members.

entries.meaning: (patent law) To include, contain, or be made up of, defining the minimum elements, whether essential or inessential to define an invention.
